race.name: TOUR DIVIDE
race.tagline: 2,745 miles from Banff to Mexico. The longest mountain bike time trial on earth. Self-supported. Unsupported. Unforgettable.

vitals.location: Banff, Alberta to Antelope Wells, New Mexico
vitals.county: Continental Divide (5 US states, 2 Canadian provinces)
vitals.date: Second Friday in June annually (Grand Depart)
vitals.registration: Free entryâ€”submit letter of intent. ITT available year-round.
vitals.prize_purse: Noneâ€”pure amateur ethos. No sponsors, no prizes.
vitals.aid_stations: Noneâ€”completely self-supported. Resupply at commercial establishments only.
vitals.cutoff_time: No official cutoff. Competitive finish ~25 days (men), ~29 days (women).

climate.primary: Everythingâ€”snow to desert heat across 2,700+ miles
climate.description: June start means snow on Canadian/Montana passes, spring mud in Wyoming, afternoon thunderstorms in Colorado's high country, and desert heat in New Mexico. Temperature swings from below freezing at 11,000+ feet to 100Â°F+ in the desert. Weather changes rapidly at altitude. Wildfires and smoke increasingly common.
challenges: Lightning storms in Colorado (especially above treeline)
60-70 mph wind gusts on exposed ridges
Extreme desert heat in final sections

terrain.primary: Mixed mountain bike terrain following the Continental Divide
terrain.surface: ~90% unpaved: 2,100 miles of gravel/dirt roads, ~60 miles singletrack, ~950 miles paved. Surfaces range from smooth gravel to unmaintained trails to rocky New Mexico terrain.
features: Fleecer Ridgeâ€”toughest climb with infamous descent
Great Divide Basinâ€”100+ miles of waterless desert
Gila Wildernessâ€”steep, rugged New Mexico mountains

logistics.explanation: Complete self-sufficiency across 2,745 miles with resupply only at commercial establishments. Mac Tyler Fox describes it as "possibly the stupidest, most awesome thing I've done to date, and I loved it as much as I hated it." Must carry days of food and water between towns spaced 100-200 miles apart, including waterless stretches like the Great Basin. True expedition logistics for 2-4 weeks with zero outside assistance permitted.

length.explanation: Brett Simpson finished in 20 days 21 hours, averaging 137 miles per day: "My goal was 22 days with a secret goal of 19 days. Due to forest fires we were re-routed and added 115 miles to our route." The 2,745-mile distance requires 2-4 weeks of continuous effort. Current record is 13 days, 2 hours (Justinas Leveika, 2024). This is expedition territory beyond ultra-endurance.

technicality.explanation: OneOfSeven Rider describes day one conditions: "The conditions ranged from beautiful crushed gravel paths to muddy single track, back to muddy logging roads and finally a very rocky Hike-a-Bike up Koko Pass." Despite epic scale, technical difficulty is moderate. Route is largely gravel and forest service roads, though weather transforms any section into technical challenge.

elevation.explanation: 200,000 feet of total climbing over the courseâ€”roughly equivalent to climbing Everest from sea level seven times. OneOfSeven Rider reports the brutal reality: "Over the next 3+ miles I barely rode my bike. My arms were as tired as my legs by the time I stopped." Daily climbing averages 2,500-4,500 feet with multiple days exceeding 4,500 feet.

climate.explanation: Edyn Teitge describes day two weather: "The day started overcast but still pretty nice. The sun even came out for a bit, but just around noon, it started raining. Up at the summit of the second pass of the day is where I met the first bit of snow." You experience every climate zone across 2,700 miles with snow possible any time at elevation.

altitude.explanation: Indiana Pass reaches 11,913 feetâ€”highest point on the route. Colorado sections regularly exceed 10,000 feet with multiple 11,000+ foot passes. Extended time above 8,000 feet throughout route with sleep deprivation compounding altitude effects. Acclimatization impossible for most starters who arrive from sea level. Sustained riding at 7,300+ feet reported by multiple riders.

adventure.explanation: The bikepacking version of the Great American Road Trip from Canada to Mexico through Whitefish, Galton Pass, Kananaskis Lakes, The Wall, and Red Pass. Daily geography changes dramatically through North America's most spectacular terrain. This is a life-defining experience riders describe as the ultimate expression of freedom across the Continental Divide.

prestige.explanation: The halo event of bikepacking ultra-racing. The longest, most challenging mountain bike time trial on the planet. Established in 2008, it has defined the genre of self-supported ultra-endurance cycling. Names like Mike Hall, Lael Wilcox, and Justinas Leveika are legends specifically because of Tour Divide. Only ~716 finishers in history since 2008.

race_quality.explanation: Paradoxically elite despite zero organization. No entry fee, no prizes, no sponsorsâ€”pure amateur ethos. The 198-rider field includes elite racers like Adam, Bryan Rogala, and Kristen Legan alongside recreational riders like Ozogan. SPOT tracking provides live race following via TrackLeaders. The minimalist approach creates a purer racing experience.

experience.explanation: Mac Tyler Fox describes lasting physical impacts: "At some point during the race, I lost feeling in them [toes]. The numbness didn't bother me too much during the ride...For weeks after finishing, I had numbness in all my toes on both feet." The suffering and beauty combine into something that reshapes how finishers see themselves forever.

community.explanation: Legendary culture built on mutual respect and shared suffering. The 2024 field included riders from recreational to elite levels: Mac Tyler Fox, Adam, JJJJustin, Ozogan, Bryan Rogala, Brett Simpson, Edyn Teitge, Kristen Legan, and Dave Gieger. Those who finish share a bond that transcends typical racing camaraderie. No commercialization preserves authentic adventure cycling values.

field_depth.explanation: Deep field with 198 riders in recent years. Elite riders like Adam, Bryan Rogala, and Kristen Legan race alongside competitive riders like Edyn Teitge and Dave Gieger. Brett Simpson finished 14th in 20 days 21 hours, demonstrating the depth required even for mid-pack placement. Competition at the front is world-class with serious athletes throughout the field.

value.explanation: No entry fee. The race costs what you spend on resupply and travel. For a 2-4 week adventure across the Continental Divide from Banff to Antelope Wells, the value is extraordinary. Hotels in resort towns can be expensive, but bivvy camping is the competitive strategy anyway. The experience-to-cost ratio is unmatched in endurance sports.

expenses.explanation: No entry fee, but real costs accumulate. JJJJustin's setup included Otso Fenrir Ti frame, Wolf Tooth Components, 100mm Fox 32 fork, dynamo hub powering kLite lightsâ€”representing significant gear investment. Flights to Banff, 2-4 weeks of resupply food, occasional hotels, and post-race travel home. Total trip budget: $1,500-3,000+ depending on style.

biased_opinion.summary: Tour Divide is bikepacking racing at its purest and most extreme. 2,745 miles from Banff to Mexico, completely self-supported, no entry fee, no prizes, no sponsorsâ€”just you, your bike, and the Continental Divide for 2-4 weeks. It's not really comparable to other races; it's an expedition that happens to be timed. The combination of distance, elevation, terrain diversity, climate extremes, and complete self-reliance creates something unique in endurance sports. With only ~716 finishers in history and a 47-60% DNF rate, completing Tour Divide joins a very exclusive club.
strengths: The definitive ultra-endurance bikepacking raceâ€”nothing else compares
Spectacular terrain variety: Canadian Rockies to New Mexico desert
Pure amateur ethosâ€”no commercialization, just adventure
Legendary community and lifetime achievement upon finishing
weaknesses: 47-60% DNF rate reflects genuine brutalityâ€”not for the underprepared
2-4 week time commitment excludes most working athletes
Equipment failures across 2,700 miles require bike mechanic skills
Mental challenge may exceed physicalâ€”isolation and sleep deprivation compound
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you have the time, preparation, and mental fortitude for the ultimate test of self-supported cycling endurance, Tour Divide is the answer. But respect what 2,745 miles alone on the Continental Divide actually means.

black_pill.title: THE MONSTER THAT BREAKS HALF OF ALL STARTERS
black_pill.reality: 47-60% of starters do not finish. Let that sink in. These are not casual cyclistsâ€”they are dedicated athletes who trained for months and committed to a 2-4 week expedition. Half of them fail anyway. Reasons: physical breakdown (feet swell, hands go numb, altitude sickness), mental defeat (alone for weeks, sleep-deprived, the doubts become overwhelming), mechanical failures beyond repair (you are 50+ miles from any bike shop), impassable weather (mud that stops all progress, snowstorms at 11,000 feet), fear (grizzly bears, lightning, exposure). The route is extremely hard on equipmentâ€”wheels, tires, and drivetrains take abuse that destroys components.
consequences: Loss of feeling in toes can last 1-4 months post-race
Something WILL go wrong mechanicallyâ€”be able to fix it yourself
100+ mile stretches with no water, no services, no cell coverage
Sleep deprivation compounds every problemâ€”3-4 hours/night for front runners
black_pill.expectation_reset: This is NOT recommended as your first bikepacking ultra. Multi-day shakedown rides (1,000km+) are essential. You need to be skilled at bike repair, nutrition management, sleep strategy, and mental resilience. The Tour Divide is called 'a monster' for a reason. Respect it or it will destroy your attempt.

final_verdict.one_liner: The longest mountain bike time trial on earthâ€”2,745 miles from Banff to Mexico, completely self-supported, pure amateur ethos.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you have serious ultra-endurance experience and can commit 2-4 weeks to the Continental Divide. Yes if you can handle complete self-sufficiency across remote terrain. Yes if you want the ultimate test. Skip if you haven't completed multi-day self-supported events. Skip if you need race organization, aid stations, or support crews. Skip if you cannot repair your own bike.
final_verdict.alternatives: Trans Am Bike Race (4,400 miles, more paved); Colorado Trail Race (500 miles, high-altitude focus); Arizona Trail Race (800 miles, desert bikepacking); Badlands (800km, self-supported in Spain)

logistics.lodging_strategy: Banff for pre-race (book early, resort town prices). During race: bivvy/wild camping saves time vs hotels. Resort towns (Breckenridge, Steamboat) expensive. Fernie hostel good value. Towns every 100-200 miles for resupply.
logistics.food: Self-supportedâ€”resupply at ~20 towns along route. Carry 2-3 days food for long stretches. Great Basin (Wyoming) has 100+ miles with no natural water. Binge at restaurants, carry Snickers and hand food for riding.
logistics.packet_pickup: No formal packet pickupâ€”show up at Banff start line. Submit letter of intent beforehand encouraged.
logistics.parking: Banff staging area. Coordinate with Whitefish-area bike shops (Glacier Cyclery) for post-race transport.

history.founder: Matthew Lee (expanded from Mike Curiak's Great Divide Race)
history.origin_story: The Great Divide Mountain Bike Route (GDMBR) was created by Adventure Cycling Association in 1997. Mike Curiak conceived the Great Divide Race in 2004, originally starting at Roosville, Montana. When Adventure Cycling added a 221-mile Canadian section in 2008, Matthew Lee amended the race to start in Banff and renamed it Tour Divide.

2016: Mike Hall sets course record of 13d 22h 51m that stood for 8 years
2017: Mike Hall tragically killed during Indian Pacific Wheel Race in Australia
2024: Justinas Leveika breaks record on full-suspension Trek Supercaliber (13d 2h 16m)
2024: Austin Killips sets women's record of 14d 23h 12m on ITT
history.reputation: The halo event of bikepacking ultra-racing. The longestâ€”arguably most challengingâ€”mountain bike time trial on the planet.

course_description.character: A 2,745-mile expedition along the Continental Divide from Canada to Mexico. The route passes through 5 US states and 2 Canadian provinces, crossing the Divide 30+ times. Terrain ranges from glaciated Canadian Rockies to Wyoming's Red Desert to Colorado's 11,000+ foot passes to New Mexico's rocky Gila Wilderness. Surface is roughly 90% unpavedâ€”mostly gravel and forest service roads with some singletrack and paved connectors. The character changes daily as you ride south through changing ecosystems, elevations, and climates.

suffering_zones.label: Canada/Montana Border
suffering_zones.desc: First major psychological milestone. Koko Claims hike-a-bike section early. Grizzly bear territory begins.

suffering_zones.label: Fleecer Ridge (Montana)
suffering_zones.desc: Toughest climb on Tour Divide. Infamous descent so steep riders report brake rotors hot enough to turn water to steam.

suffering_zones.label: Great Divide Basin (Wyoming)
suffering_zones.desc: 100+ miles of Red Desert. Second-longest stretch without natural water. Peanut butter mud if it rains. Psychological wasteland.

suffering_zones.label: Indiana Pass (Colorado)
suffering_zones.desc: Highest point at 11,913 feet. 4,038 feet of climbing over 23 miles. 13 miles riding above 11,000 feet. Lightning danger.

suffering_zones.label: Gila to Antelope Wells (New Mexico)
suffering_zones.desc: Final 250 miles through deteriorating roads, rocky terrain, desert heat. Last 123 miles from Silver City have no services. Mental finish line torture.

course_description.signature_challenge: The complete packageâ€”2,745 miles of self-supported suffering through every climate zone, every terrain type, and every mental state across 2-4 weeks on the Continental Divide.

In 2015, Lael raced the Tour Divide â€“ an event that follows the route â€“ and set a new womenâ€™s course record despite having to ride herself to an emergency room en route to deal with a persistent breathing issue. Just two weeks later, she rode to the start from her home in Alaska, took on the trail for a second time and lowered her own record by another day and a half.
